text: thank you so much for doing this and
coming along first of all as the
best-selling female author in Turkey and
someone who's written extensively on
women's rights in your many novels how
do you see the state of gender equality
in Turkey at the moment all I have to
say I am I'm worried about so many
things
twick is a very complicated
multi-layered country it's not easy to
summarize it's not easy to categorize it
so lots of things positive and negative
can happen at the same time it is a very
patriarchal male-dominated country and
that said there are many Turkish and
Kurdish women who are incredibly visible
vocal in many areas arts academia
medicine you know media however there's
one area in which women are almost
non-existent and that is politics you
know that the proportion of you know
female representation is still quite low
in Turkey and women's dishes are always
you know postpones because they're never
seen as a priority
so let's talk more about political
representation if you look at the
manifestos of all the parties competing
in this coming election there are
clearly many women candidates standing
and women's issues are undoubtedly being
discussed but do you think when it comes
to voting for a woman it's different you
know at first glance it seems like this
year particularly in this elections that
the number of female candidates have
increased it's true but it's not enough
you know when we look at the the
population it's a vast country we're
talking about and and the problems of
women really immense deeply rooted I do
not see this change enough and I do not
believe that every party has done enough
for increasing female representation and
over the years especially in the last
year's we have had so many conservative
male politicians in Turkey top down
telling Turkish women how many kids we
should have three preferably five you
know whether c-section is okay or not
telling us even we had the tip Deputy
Prime Minister who said that Turkish
women should not laugh out loudly in the
public space because it wouldn't be
proper we have had ministers saying that
you know with Turkish women should focus
on their motherhood this is their
primary career we have had politicians
top-level politicians saying that they
did not believe in gender equality and I
can give you so many examples so when
you hear such statements one after
another one after another in a country
in which there is already so much
domestic violence and so many problems
it doesn't help it doesn't help to
improve women's women's issues so I find
this attitude
are you hopeful there will be better
political representation of women at the
next parliament then I'm always half
pessimistic half optimistic I think what
makes me pessimistic is when I look at
the structure you know the political
structures the political mentalities I
am I find it a bit gloomy however I look
at the people you know I focus on the
people particularly youth women
subcultures minorities you know the
Middle East and Turkey these are very
diverse societies teaming with colours
and energy then I am more hopeful for
the future
thanks so much thank you
